far more complex than it needed to be explained given that most people watching this are students. The answer was no-where-near made out clearly, and I would suggest that anyone trying to grasp the basic concept go look elsewhere. the way electron shells work (at A-level), is that each shell has an energy level that increases the further it is from the nucleus. within these are sub shells, that have smaller differences between energy levels, and finally within those, exist orbitals. The orbitals hold the electrons, and each orbital can hold two at a time. There are different types of sub-shells: S, P, and D are the basics. the S sub shells have 1 orbital, the Ps 3, and the Ds 5. this means that a full first shell can have a maximum of 2 electrons (1 full S orbital), a full 2nd shell can have a maximum of 8 electrons (1 full S orbital, and 3 full P orbitals). Finally, the 3rd level can have a maximum of 18 electrons (1 full S orbital, 3 full P orbitals, and 5 full D orbitals). remember that each orbital can hold 2 electrons. There is much more to this, but hopefully that helps. Btw, each energy energy level is labelled 1, 2, 3, and so on, and the number of sub shells in each is the same as that number.

Pauli's exclusion principle is wrong since there is only one type of electrons where all free electrons that emitted from an electron-gun will be deflected to a spot on a screen behind the cathode tube after interacting with a fixed external magnetic field. It's wrong to believe that every orbital will be filled with two electrons each with different intrinsic spins since there is only one type of electrons. We focus too much attention on valence electrons and we neglecting the important of nucleus structure. It's the uniqueness of the nucleus structure that molds the orbitals of those stationary electrons. Dissipation of heat or absorption of heat will take place during a chemical reaction that affecting the angular momentum of those nucleons that causing its nucleus structure to flex in certain orientation and configuration that reorientation of orbitals that will cause it to have different physical and chemical characteristics before and after a chemical reaction. water is a bent molecule simply because electron pairs are too big to fit on the same plane...well on screen it might seem that putting them side by side makes them seem closer but actually, one lone pair is at the back of the screen and one lone pair is coming out of the screen towards you, where they can have the maximum distance away from each other BUT we don't draw wedges or dashed lines, simply because they are not atoms, however, if they were atoms instead of lone pairs of electrons, they would have a more or less TETRAHEDRAL shape. In simple terms, as described in this video, water gets bent because the 2 lone pairs, having the same charge, repel each other and that's why they want to maximize the distance away from each other to avoid strains and as a consequence, the hydrogen atoms get bent as well

This video poorly explains orbitals. So for those who still don’t understand orbitals: Orbitals are just places around the nucleus where there is a high probability of finding an electron. That’s pretty much it. Orbitals can have different shapes (s, p, d, and f). Orbitals and orbits are NOT the same. Orbits are the paths of electrons, which we cannot know because of Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle (The more you know how fast something is going the less you would know it’s position in space). So again: Orbitals are just places around the nucleus where there is a high probability of finding an electron. Orbitals may seem complicated at first, but they are very easy when you look deeper into them. If you have any questions you can just reply. I will be making a video on my channel about orbitals really soon.

Actually, a completely flooded planet has A LOT to do with quantum mechanics. Atomic orbital wavefunctions are based on the spherical harmonics, which are the solutions of the classical wave equation for the standing modes of waves on a completely flooded planet. While the solution of this problem was thought useless at the time, it is central to nearly all atomic and molecular quantum mechanics, demonstrating that sometimes there is value in solving a problem for which there is no obvious application at the time.

I think the very wrong thing the chemistry teacher does about teaching bonds is by presenting as if electrons of two atoms get linked. The reality is that the whole chemical reaction starts taking place only because of proton's attraction - electrons just either get attracted by protons or get repelled by neighboring electrons. Meaning, protons lead and electrons follow.

I had bad experiences with orbitals in class, because it was sooo confusing when my chemistry teacher tried to draw it on a whiteboard! Especially when he tried to explain the "partially filled" p orbitals and sp2 orbitals in ethene. Note: partially filled orbitals means there is only ONE electron in those orbitals.
The thought cafe did a great job on showing how exactly the bonds form, without complicating learning by saying which orbitals are partially filled or not.
Note to self:
sp3 hybridization is only for an atom which has one or more single bonds with other atoms, i.e. H2O
sp2 hybridization is only for an atom which has ONE double bond with another atom, e.g. ethene
sp hybridization is only for an atom which has TWO double bonds with other TWO atoms, e.g. CO2 OR have ONE triple bond with another atom, e.g. N2.

I see a few comments saying "stigma and phi bonds make no sense". I believe the first (single) bonds that form are stigma bonds then the 2nd/3rd bonds (i.e. when it becomes double/triple bonds) are known as phi bonds. It's based on drawing out your bonds. It makes more sense when you draw out the molecules,  their valence electrons, and then you draw the first bonds stigma bonds. The rest (the bonds that make your electrons happy) are your phi bonds. You do not actually see the atoms in the molecule. WHat you see is a projected image, generated by the interaction of a very thin charged needle with the electron density of a molecule. The molecules that they use to make those atomic force scannings are planar, and have high electron densities in aromatic rings. Looking closely, you can see brighter spots in between carbon atoms, and more diffuse smudges outside of the rings where hydrogen atoms are. But these images are not three-dimensional.

There are actually more elements that have the ability to disobey the "octet rule" than obey it, mainly b/c they canNOT make an octet due to a deficiency in electrons (Ex: Be and B) or b/c they have "d" &/or "f" atomic orbitals. THUS, elements obeying the octet rule utilize only their "s" and "p" atomic orbitals as their valence orbitals. Once you hit the period #3 "d" orbitals are available, and once you hit period #4 "f" orbitals are available.
